column1: Tianjin is the pinyin romanization of the Chinese characters 天津
column2: which mean "Heavenly Ford" or "Ford of Heaven".

column1: The origin of the name is obscure. One folk etymology is that it was an homage to the patriotic Chu poet Qu Yuan
column2: whose "Li Sao" includes the verse "... departing from the Ford of Heaven at dawn ..." (朝發軔於天津兮
column3: zhāo fārèn yú Tiānjīn xī). Another is that it honors a former name of the girl
column4: a Chinese constellation recorded under the name Tianjin in the Astronomical Record section of the Book of Sui. A third is that it derives from a place name noted in the River Record of the History of Jin. The most common is that it was bestowed by the Yongle Emperor of the Ming
column5: who crossed Tianjin's Gu River on his way south to overthrow his nephew
column6: the Jianwen Emperor.

column1: The land where Tianjin is located today was created in between 900-1300 CE by sedimentation of various rivers entering the sea at Bohai Gulf
column3: which entered the open sea in this area at one point. The construction of the Grand Canal under the Sui dynasty helped the future development of Tianjin as the canal ran from Hangzhou to the Beijing and Tianjin region by 609 CE. Grain from southern China was regularly transported to the north through the canal and was used during the subsequent dynasties. Tianjin begins to be increasingly mentioned in records during the Song dynasty and gains importance during the Yuan dynasty. Tianjin experienced development under the Yuan and became a prime location for the storage of goods and grains. Tianjin became a garrison town and shipping station during the Ming dynasty. It became a center of commerce and prosperity by the 17th century.

column1: During the Qing dynasty (1644–1911) Tianjin Prefecture or Zhou (州) was established in 1725
column2: and Tianjin County was established within the prefecture in 1731. Later it was upgraded to an urban prefecture or Fu (府) before becoming a relay station (駐地) under the command of the Viceroy of Zhili.

Tianjin Export Processing Zone is located to the northeast of TEDA with a planned area of 2.54 km2 (0.98 sq mi). The area developed in the first phase is 1 m2. column13: colorful figurine depicting a variety of vivid characters
column15: which can be folded to a fraction of their full sizes and are noted for portability.

column1: Tianjin cuisine places a heavy focus on seafood
column2: due to Tianjin's proximity to the sea.  It can be further classified into several varieties
column3: including the rough (Chinese: 粗; pinyin: cū)
column4: smooth (simplified Chinese: 细; traditional Chinese: 細; pinyin: xì)
column5: and high (Chinese: 高; pinyin: gāo). Prominent menus include the Eight Great Bowls (Chinese: 八大碗; pinyin: Bādà wǎn)
column6: a combination of eight mainly meat dishes
column7: and the Four Great Stews (Chinese: 四大扒; pinyin: sì dà bā)
column8: actually referring to a very large number of stews
column9: including chicken
column10: duck
column11: seafood

column1: The four delicacies of Tianjin include Goubuli baozi

column3: Erduoyan Zhagao (Chinese: 耳朵眼炸糕; pinyin: erduoyǎn zhà gāo) and Maobuwen Jiaozi (Chinese: 猫不闻饺子; pinyin: māo bù wén jiǎozi). Well-known foods include Caoji donkey meat
column5: Luji Tangmian Zhagao

column8: Guobacai of Dafulai

column10: which was a famous calling-card of Tianjin in the aspect of cuisine.

column1: Tianjin Binhai International Airport is located in Dongli District roughly 13 km (8 mi) away from downtown area. The city is also served by the new Beijing Daxing International Airport in Beijing.
Tianjin Binhai International Airport now has a terminal building which covers an area of 25
column3: 000 sq ft)
column4: a merchandise warehouse which covers an area of 29
column6: 000 sq ft) and runways measuring 3.6 km (2.2 mi) in total. It has a grade 4E airstrip
column7: which all kinds of large aircraft can take off from and land safely on. Tianjin Binhai International Airport has 59 flight routes
column8: connecting 48 cities
column9: including 30 domestic cities and 17 foreign cities. Airline companies like Japan Airlines
column10: All Nippon Airways
column11: Korean Air
column13: Singapore Airlines Cargo and Martinair Holland all have flights to Tianjin Binhai International Airport.

column1: Tianjin port is the world's top-level and China's largest artificial deep water harbor
column2: and the throughput capacity ranks fifth in the world. Located in Binhai Economic Zone
column3: a national new economic zone of China
column4: Tianjin harbor is the port of call of international cruises visiting the wider area
column5: including Beijing.

column1: Tianjin's harbor area of Binhai/TEDA has a modern
column2: high speed rubber tired tram system
column3: which is the first of its kind in China and Asia. Constructed in 2006
column4: this marked a return of the tram to Tianjin
column5: which once had an extensive standard steel-wheeled tramway network. The original Tianjin tram network was constructed by a Belgian company in 1904 and opened in 1906. It was the first citywide tramway system in China. It closed in 1972.

column1: The Tianjin Metro is formerly operated by two companies
column2: Tianjin Metro General Corporation and Tianjin Binhai Mass Transit Development Company. However
column4: the two companies merged as Tianjin Rail Transit Group Corporation. They are currently under heavy expansion from five to nine lines. Six lines are currently operating both in the City and the Binhai area. As of April 2019
column5: the entire network of Tianjin Metro has 155 stations and 6 lines.

column1: Construction work on the Tianjin Metro started on July 4
column2: 1970. It was the second metro to be built in China and commenced service in 1984. The total length of track was 7.4 kilometers (5 mi). The metro service was suspended on October 9
column3: 2001 for reconstruction. The original line is now part of Line 1 of the new metro system. It was reopened to the public in June 2006. The track was extended to 26
column5: 272.469 mi) and there are a total of 22 stations.  Construction work on Line 2 and Line 3 was completed in 2012 and the two lines are now in operation. Several new metro lines are planned.

column1: There was two rapid transit operators in Tianjin. In 2017
column2: the two companies merged as Tianjin Rail Transit Group Corporation.

column1: Tianjin Binhai Mass Transit Development Company
There are several railway stations in the city
column2: Tianjin railway station being the principal one. It was built in 1888. The station was initially located at Wangdaozhuang (simplified Chinese: 旺道庄; traditional Chinese: 旺道莊; pinyin: Wàngdàozhuāng). The station was later moved to Laolongtou (simplified Chinese: 老龙头; traditional Chinese: 老龍頭; pinyin: Lǎolóngtóu) on the banks of the Hai He River in 1892
column3: so the station was renamed Laolongtou Railway Station. The station was rebuilt from scratch in 1988. The rebuilding work began on April 15
column5: 1988. The Tianjin Railway Station is also locally called the 'East Station'
column6: due to its geographical position. In January 2007
column7: the station began another long-term restructuring project to modernize the facility and as part of the larger Tianjin transport hub project involving Tianjin Metro lines 2
column9: and 9 as well as the Tianjin-Beijing High-speed rail.

column1: Tianjin West railway station and Tianjin North railway station are also major railway stations in Tianjin. There is also Tanggu railway station is located in the important port area of Tanggu District
column2: and Binhai railway station and Binhai North railway station located in TEDA
column3: to the north of Tanggu. There are several other railway stations in the city that do not handle passenger traffic. Construction on a Beijing-Tianjin high-speed rail began on July 4

Some roads and bridges have retained names that hark back to the Republic of China era (1912–1949) such as Minquan Gate and Beiyang Road. Like with most cities in China
column2: many roads in Tianjin are named after Chinese provinces and cities. Also
column3: Tianjin is unlike Beijing
column4: in that very few roads run parallel to the major four cardinal directions.

column1: Tianjin has three ring roads. The Inner and Middle Ring Roads are not closed
column2: traffic-controlled roadways and some often have traffic light intersections. The Outer Ring Road is the closest thing to a highway-level ring road
column3: although traffic is often chaotic.

column1: Outer Ring Road (waihuan)Tianjin's roads often finish in dao (Chinese: 道; lit.: 'avenue')
column2: xian (simplified Chinese: 线; traditional Chinese: 線; lit.: 'line'). These are most often used for highways and through routes. The terms lu (Chinese: 路; lit.: 'road'). Jie (Chinese: 街; lit.: 'street') are rare. As Tianjin's roads are rarely in a cardinal compass direction
column3: jing (simplified Chinese: 经; traditional Chinese: 經; lit.: 'avenue') roads and wei (simplified Chinese: 纬; traditional Chinese: 緯; lit.: 'avenue') roads often appear
column4: which attempt to run more directly north–south and east–west
column5: respectively.

column1: Residents of Tianjin participate in indigenous religions
column2: such as the veneration of the goddess Mazu. In addition
column3: Tianjin has a Buddhist Temple of Great Compassion
column4: a Catholic St. Joseph's Cathedral (Laoxikai Church)
column5: a Catholic Our Lady of Victory Church (Wanghailou Church). A Roman Catholic Diocese of Tianjin exists. According to the Chinese General Social Survey of 2009
column6: Christians constitute 1.51% of the city's population. Tianjin has been described as a historically "strong center" of Islam in China. Northwestern Tianjin is traditionally the location of the Muslim quarter of the city
column7: where they have lived for centuries near the city's huge Great Mosque
column8: Qingzhen si
column9: founded in 1703. Other mosques include the Dahuoxiang Mosque.

column5: Bagua Zhang and others lived or are living in the city. The districts most famous for martial arts in the city are Hong Qiao and Nankai
column6: and martial artists abound in public green spaces such as Xigu Park and the Tianjin Water Park.
